column2: Ajahn Pasanno reads from P. A. Payutto’s _Buddhist Economics_ and _A Constitution for Living_ and answers questions related to the topic of right livelihood.

column6: Session title
Text
Buddhist Economics p. 19; Buddhist Economics p. 36.
Lottery numbers?...Is the problem that the monks have the right numbers so everyone flocks to them?
Could you talk more about the particular professions that the Buddha laid out as wrong livelihood? Why is being in the military not on the list?
AN 5.177: Trades
The widow of a wealthy man divests from Singha Beer.
Is growing grapes right livelihood?
The son of a winemaking family lives on the land but doesn't participate in wine production.
Can you speak about the people who sell these things [intoxicants] versus those who make them?
A clerk at an organic food store asks about selling wine.
If the person selling the product enjoys selling it and the person buying it enjoys the product, what is the unpleasant consequence?
What about people whose livelihood falls into one of these categories [AN 5.177] but they are convinced that it's good for the world or that it had to be done?
about the nuances involved in the activities comprising wrong livelihood.
Is caffeine an intoxicant?
about meat eating.
Different people will be comfortable at different degrees of contentment and ability to live simply.|P. A. Payutto
The Buddha taught the five forms of wrong livelihood [AN 5.177]. This is from the producer side. Is there a similar teaching from the consumer side?
What is the view on medical or pharmaceutical professions?
What about things that have an ostensibly benign purpose, such as pesticides and fertilizers used for raising food, but then in fact have quite harmful effects?
Is there any instruction from the Buddha about how to deal with profit-motivated pharmaceutical research decisions?
Some people want to help but find themselves in situations in which profit dictates the priorities. How can they protect their integrity in such situations?
Ajahn Karuniko studies engineering, then quits a job in the arms industry to become a monk.
It's not easy giving up the things we're used to in order to follow the path.
When quitting a job, should you consider the welfare of the next person who will fill it?
Right Livelihood isn't about judging other people's livelihood.
about Temple Grandon designing low-anxiety slaughterhouses.

The Buddha's function was not to make grand pronouncements that apply universally, everywhere, all the time. He gave guidelines to relfect a variety of circumstances, personal effects, social effects, and then make a decision from there.
about thinking versus feeling out the quality of the heart in decision making.
